author: Marianna Papadakis
title: CEO cannot recall payments to Shorten union
text:
Former ACI chief executive Peter Robinson told the inquiry he had no knowledge of payments to the union. by Marianna Papadakis The head of glass works company ACI, which paid hundreds of thousands of dollars to a union then headed by Opposition leader Bill Shorten, has told a royal commission into trade union corruption that he did not know about the payments.
The Australian Workers Union received around $480,000 over a three-year period for education and training from ACI during a period in which the company was negotiating with the union over an enterprise bargaining deal in 2003.
But former ACI chief executive Peter Robinson, who was there from 2003 until 2005, during the relevant period, told the inquiry he had no knowledge of any of the payments to the union.
Denials When presented with invoices for "paid education" amounting to around $160,000 per year over a three-year period by counsel assisting the commission Jeremy Stoljar, SC, Mr Robinson said he could not explain the expenses.
"Your evidence is you have no idea how they came to be paid or what they were for," Mr Stoljar said.
"Correct," Mr Robinson replied.
Mr Stoljar said previous evidence in private hearings to the commission by an employee relations manager Michael Gilhome was that he "certainly would have discussed these transactions" with Mr Robinson.
 But Mr Robinson denied any discussions took place.
The company's general manager of human resources Brendan Mitchell to whom Mr Gilhome also reported at one stage said he too knew nothing about the invoices.
Enterprise bargaining deal Mr Gilhome told the commission later in the day he led discussions for ACI for the enterprise bargaining deal, while Cesar Melhem who was then a union official but later succeeded Mr Shorten as AWU national secretary, led them for the union.
Mr Gilhome said he approved two invoices amounting to around $150,000 in line with an agreement to pay the AWU for training. He said he "would have discussed" payments with Mr Melhem and Mr Robinson.
Mr Gilhome said he did not see a conflict of interest in giving money to the union to support training and offset the costs of the Victorian branch for Mr Melhem's travel around the country for the union. He said payments to the union stopped in 2005.
He admitted one invoice for $5500 for "paid education" in the early 2000s was "false" and was in reality in accordance with the company's agreement to pay for 12 of its workers' union memberships for a year, following a union demarcation dispute at its Spotswood plant.
"It was quite a common thing in those years for companies and the industries generally to pay for membership for some unions in order to have jobs going on," Mr Gilhome said.
It follows evidence from several Thiess John Holland senior executives earlier in the week concerning $300,000 in payments, delivered as $100,000 a year, by the company to the union in exchange for a favourable enterprise bargaining deal for the $2.5 billion EastLink road project in Melbourne in the mid-2000s.
False invoices Former Thiess John Holland executive Julian Rzesniowiecki told the inquiry on Tuesday four of 28 invoices he authorised, amounting to around $100,000 in payments to the union, were false.
Mr Rzesniowiecki said the invoices were to disguise the company's funding of an on-site union organiser, in line with a pre-existing agreement between the company and the union that was forged by Mr Shorten and another senior executive Stephen Sasse.
Mr Shorten's representative Neil Clelland QC sought to discredit Mr Rzesniowiecki's testimony in a second day of evidence on Wednesday arguing he had not been frank with the commission in his evidence about there being a pre-existing agreement.
"I don't accept that," Mr Rzesniowiecki said.
Mr Rzesniowiecki said the AWU had made a claim for money and that Mr Shorten was present at a December 2004 meeting where the arrangement was discussed.
Mr Sasse told the inquiry on Monday he negotiated with Mr Shorten in the lead-up to the bargaining deal, around about September and October 2004, over funding the on-site organiser.
Mr Sasse said it appeared the $300,000 in payments to the union approximated the $300,000 he initially discussed with Mr Shorten and that the "relevant documentation was deliberately falsified".
Mr Shorten told the commission in evidence on July 8 and 9, he did not recall any discussion with Mr Sasse about funding an organiser.
Mr Shorten denied any involvement in, or knowledge of, the AWU's issuing of bogus invoices to the company saying that he left details of the project to his successor as AWU national secretary, Cesar Melhem.
